Define coordination number. State its value in (i) hcp/fcc and (ii) bcc.
answer: Coordination number is the number of nearest neighbours around a particle. For hcp/fcc it is 12; for bcc it is 8.

text: Give two differences between crystalline and amorphous solids.
answer: Crystalline: long-range order, sharp melting point, anisotropic. Amorphous: short-range order, melt over a range, isotropic.

text: Derive $a=\dfrac{4r}{\sqrt{3}}$ for bcc.
answer: In bcc, atoms touch along the body diagonal. Hence $\sqrt{3}a=4r \Rightarrow a=\dfrac{4r}{\sqrt{3}}$.

text: Name the three Bravais lattices of the cubic system with one example each.
answer: Simple cubic (polonium), body-centred cubic (sodium), face-centred cubic (copper or aluminium).

text: Write the density expression for a cubic crystal and explain the symbols.
answer: $\rho=\dfrac{Z M}{N_A a^3}$, where $Z$ = atoms/formula units per cell, $M$ = molar mass, $N_A$ = Avogadro’s number, $a$ = edge length.

text: Why does a Frenkel defect not change the density of the crystal?
answer: Because no ions are lost; a smaller ion shifts from a lattice site to an interstitial site, so mass and volume remain essentially the same.

text: Copper crystallises fcc with $a=361\,\text{pm}$. Calculate $r$.
Give two differences between p-type and n-type semiconductors.
answer: p-type: group-13 dopant, holes majority carriers, Fermi level near valence band. n-type: group-15 dopant, electrons majority carriers, Fermi level near conduction band.

text: Show that packing efficiency in simple cubic is about 52.4%.
answer: For sc, $a=2r$ and there is 1 atom per cell. Efficiency $=\dfrac{\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}}{a^{3}}\times100=\dfrac{\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}}{8r^{3}}\times100=\dfrac{\pi}{6}\times100\approx52.4\%$.

Define Miller indices and obtain the indices of a plane cutting axes at $2a,\,\infty,\,\infty$ in a cubic crystal.
answer: Miller indices $(hkl)$ are reciprocals of intercepts (reduced to smallest integers). Intercepts: $2a,\infty,\infty$. Reciprocals: $\tfrac{1}{2},0,0$. Indices: $(200)$.

text: Write the formula for interplanar spacing $d_{hkl}$ in cubic crystals.
What are F-centres? State their effect on colour.
answer: F-centres are electron-occupied anion vacancies. They absorb visible light and impart colour, e.g., yellow NaCl.

text: State the coordination numbers in sc, bcc and fcc.
Why are ionic solids brittle?
answer: Shear displaces layers so like-charged ions come close; strong repulsions cause cleavage along planes.

text: Derive the packing efficiency for face-centred cubic (fcc).
answer: In fcc, atoms touch along the face diagonal: $\sqrt{2}a=4r \Rightarrow a=2\sqrt{2}r$. Unit-cell volume $=a^{3}=(2\sqrt{2}r)^{3}=16\sqrt{2}r^{3}$. With $Z=4$, total sphere volume $=4\times\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}=\tfrac{16}{3}\pi r^{3}$. Packing efficiency $=\dfrac{\tfrac{16}{3}\pi r^{3}}{16\sqrt{2}r^{3}}\times100=\dfrac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}}\times100\approx74\%$.

text: Show that the packing efficiency in body-centred cubic (bcc) is about 68%.
answer: In bcc, $\sqrt{3}a=4r \Rightarrow a=\tfrac{4r}{\sqrt{3}}$. Cell volume $=a^{3}=\tfrac{64r^{3}}{3\sqrt{3}}$. With $Z=2$, sphere volume $=2\times\tfrac{4}{3}\pi r^{3}=\tfrac{8}{3}\pi r^{3}$. Efficiency $=\dfrac{\tfrac{8}{3}\pi r^{3}}{\tfrac{64r^{3}}{3\sqrt{3}}}\times100=\dfrac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8}\times100\approx68\%$.

text: Using Bragg’s law, find $\lambda$ if first-order reflection $(n=1)$ occurs at $\theta=30^{\circ}$ from planes with $d=2.50\,\text{\AA}$.
An fcc metal has $a=400\,\text{pm}$ and $M=60\,\text{g mol}^{-1}$. Calculate its density.
answer: For fcc, $Z=4$. Convert $a=4.00\times10^{-8}\,\text{cm}$; $a^{3}=6.40\times10^{-23}\,\text{cm}^{3}$. Then $\rho=\dfrac{Z M}{N_A a^{3}}=\dfrac{4\times60}{6.022\times10^{23}\times6.40\times10^{-23}}=\dfrac{240}{38.54}\approx6.23\,\text{g cm}^{-3}$.

text: Differentiate Schottky, Frenkel and metal-excess (anion vacancy with F-centre) defects with their effects on density and conductivity.
answer: Schottky: equal cation/anion vacancies; density decreases; ionic conductivity increases slightly via vacancy migration. Frenkel: cation moves to interstitial; density unchanged; ionic conductivity via interstitial migration increases. Metal-excess (anion vacancy with electron at F-centre): density nearly unchanged; increases electronic conductivity and imparts colour.

text: A ccp array of $X^{-}$ has $Y^{+}$ in one-third of octahedral voids. Find the formula of the compound.
answer: Let number of $X^{-}$ ions $=N$. Octahedral voids $=N$; $Y^{+}=\tfrac{N}{3}$. Formula $=Y_{N/3}X_{N}\Rightarrow YX_{3}$.

text: Explain the origin of n-type and p-type semiconductors using band theory and doping.
answer: Intrinsic Si has a small band gap. n-type: doping with group-15 (P/As) introduces donor levels just below the conduction band; electrons are majority carriers; Fermi level shifts upward. p-type: doping with group-13 (B/Al) introduces acceptor levels just above the valence band; holes are majority carriers; Fermi level shifts downward.

text: Silver (fcc) has $\rho=10.5\,\text{g cm}^{-3}$, $a=409\,\text{pm}$, and $M=107.9\,\text{g mol}^{-1}$. Compute $N_A$ from these data.
answer: For fcc, $Z=4$. Convert $a=4.09\times10^{-8}\,\text{cm}$; $a^{3}=6.85\times10^{-23}\,\text{cm}^{3}$. From $\rho=\dfrac{Z M}{N_A a^{3}}$, we get $N_A=\dfrac{Z M}{\rho a^{3}}=\dfrac{4\times107.9}{10.5\times6.85\times10^{-23}}\approx6.0\times10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1}$.

An element crystallizes in bcc. If $\rho=8.0\,\text{g cm}^{-3}$ and $a=300\,\text{pm}$, how many atoms are present in $0.24\,\text{g}$ of the element?
answer: Mass per unit cell $=\rho a^{3}=8.0\times(3.00\times10^{-8})^{3}=2.16\times10^{-22}\,\text{g}$. Each bcc cell has 2 atoms, so mass per atom $=1.08\times10^{-22}\,\text{g}$. Number of atoms in $0.24\,\text{g}=\dfrac{0.24}{1.08\times10^{-22}}\approx2.22\times10^{21}$.

text: An alloy crystallizes in ccp. The radius of the host atom is $140\,\text{pm}$. Calculate the edge length and the density if $M=70\,\text{g mol}^{-1}$.
A crystal of NaCl turns yellow when heated in sodium vapour. Explain the defect and the origin of colour.
answer: Heating in sodium vapour creates anion vacancies that are occupied by electrons (F-centres). These electrons absorb in the visible region and impart yellow colour. This is a metal-excess defect due to anion vacancies.

text: Distinguish ferromagnetism, antiferromagnetism and ferrimagnetism with one example each.
answer: Ferromagnetism: parallel alignment of magnetic moments; strong magnetization; e.g., Fe, Co, Ni. Antiferromagnetism: antiparallel equal moments cancel; net magnetization zero; e.g., MnO. Ferrimagnetism: antiparallel unequal moments; small net magnetization; e.g., Fe$_3$O$_4$ (magnetite).

text: In a ccp lattice of O$^{2-}$, if Al$^{3+}$ occupies two-thirds of the octahedral voids, show that the compound is Al$_2$O$_3$.
answer: Let O$^{2-}=N$. Octahedral voids $=N$. Number of Al$^{3+}$ ions $=\tfrac{2N}{3}$. Formula $=\text{Al}_{2N/3}\text{O}_{N}$. Dividing by $N/3$ gives Al$_2$O$_3$.
